item.title: Q. and A.: Six Things to Know About Iran’s Elections
item.description: A look at the vote and its implications as Iranians move to select a new Parliament and membership in the Assembly of Experts, an influential panel.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A reformists’ campaign rally for the coming parliamentary elections in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: Rights Group Reports Deepening Violence in Burundi
item.description: Human Rights Watch said it had found “an alarming new pattern of abductions and possible disappearances” in the Central African country.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: A security officer in Bujumbura, Burundi, during the election last year.

item.title: Indonesia’s Top Court Rules Against Educators in Sexual Assault Case
item.description: The Supreme Court reinstated convictions and prison sentences for the two men, who denied abusing children at a prestigious international school.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Ferdinand Tjiong, left, a teaching assistant at the Jakarta Intercultural School, and Neil Bantleman, a Canadian administrator there, in an Indonesian detention cell in April.

item.title: Sinosphere: China, Facing Land Shortages, Encourages Saving Space 6 Feet Under
item.description: A directive that encourages family members to be buried together or to have their remains disposed of in environmentally friendly ways has drawn criticism online.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: A worker tending graves at a public cemetery in Shanghai. The Chinese government is urging burial arrangements that will conserve land and protect the environment.

item.title: Jimmy Savile Inquiry Accuses BBC of Failing to Report Sexual Abuse
item.description: A three-year investigation concluded that the TV personality had raped at least eight people during his time at the company, including an 8-year-old.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Jimmy Savile, who worked for the BBC for several decades, in London in 2002.

item.title: As China’s Economic Picture Turns Uglier, Beijing Applies Airbrush
item.description: With troubles threatening to undermine confidence in the Communist Party, leaders are tightening the flow of information.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China is trying to solidify support at a time when doubts are swirling about his ability to manage the country’s financial and economic troubles.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Private Prisons Are Cashing In on Refugees’ Desperation
item.description: From Australia to Austria to America, governments are relying on for-profit contractors to warehouse detainees. It’s bad policy.
item.dc:creator: ANTONY LOEWENSTEIN
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The South Texas Family Residential Center in Dilley, Texas.

item.title: Sinosphere: Ex-Official in China Blames Torture for Confession, News Outlet Reports
item.description: The accusations raise deeper questions about the broader crackdown on graft promoted by President Xi Jinping.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: At a signing ceremony in Beijing in 2013, Paul Deighton, second from left, then commercial secretary to the British Treasury, shook hands with Xu Yongsheng, then deputy director of China’s National Energy Administration.

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Some Dissidents Will Be Allowed a Single Trip Overseas, an Activist Says
item.description: Officials contacted half a dozen former prisoners, who were incarcerated during a 2003 crackdown on dissidents, and told them that they could make one trip abroad.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Syrian Minister’s Wife Named to Assess Mental Health of the Displaced
item.description: Shukria Mekdad’s appointment has led critics to question the World Health Organization’s impartiality, as her husband is a defender of the government’s war effort.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: U.N. vehicles escorted a Red Crescent convoy carrying humanitarian aid in the rebel-held Eastern Ghouta area, on the outskirts of Damascus on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Progress Reported in North Korea Talks
item.description: The United States and China have agreed on a draft resolution to expand United Nations Security Council sanctions against North Korea over its latest nuclear test.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Students Injured in Clash
item.description: University guards fired rubber bullets and tear gas after disruption at a student council event, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Opposition Figure Sentenced
item.description: The figure, Ibrahim Sharif, the former secretary general of the National Democratic Action Society, was convicted of inciting hatred.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Australia Announces Rise in Spending for Military
item.description: Australia cited China’s recent activity in announcing the robust increase, which includes the biggest expansion of its navy since World War II.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia speaking on Thursday at a presentation of a defense white paper.

item.title: In Reversal, Egypt Says Terrorists Downed Russian Jet Over Sinai
item.description: After months of cautious silence, Egypt acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that terrorists had downed the Russian jet that broke up over its Sinai Peninsula in October.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.media:credit: Maxim Grigoryev/Russia's Emergency Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Wreckage from the Russian jetliner in Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula last year.

item.title: Bolivian President Concedes Defeat in Term-Limit Referendum
item.description: The measure would have allowed President Evo Morales to run for a fourth term, but it lost narrowly in a vote held Sunday.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:description: A measure that would have allowed President Evo Morales of Bolivia, shown on Wednesday, to run for a fourth term was defeated in a referendum.

item.title: A New Ruling on Marijuana in Canada
item.description: A Federal Court decision that prescription holders could grow their own supply for medical purposes adds to the confusion over the drug’s legal status.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tending to a marijuana plant at a greenhouse belonging to Tweed, a licensed producer of pot based in Smiths Falls, Ontario.

item.title: American in Iran Jail With Son
item.description: The wife of Baquer Namazi, a former Unicef official, said she thought her husband had been sent to Evin Prison, where their son, Siamak Namazi is being held.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Treasury Plan for Puerto Rico Favors Pensions Over Bondholders
item.description: A plan from the Treasury Department to ease Puerto Rico’s debt crisis would put pension payments ahead of payments to bondholders, which may rattle the muni market.
item.dc:creator: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
item.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juliana Soto and Edwin Morales are teachers in Puerto Rico. A proposal by the Treasury Department would put pension payments to public employees ahead of payments to bondholders.

item.title: Q. And A.: Assessing the Shifting Military and Political Calculus in Libya
item.description: A breakthrough in its tangled civil war, particularly in war-ravaged Benghazi, thrust Libya back into the headlines this week.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A soldier in Benghazi, Libya, on Tuesday. Militia forces unexpectedly broke a long deadlock in the city this week, claiming major gains against the Islamic State.
